title: In Dialogue With Nature
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGFN1001
description: This course is an intellectual pursuit across various natural sciences including the two most fundamental ones, physical and biological sciences. Ancient Greek philosophers took the lead in exploring the physical world and the world of life with reason and hence laid the foundations of natural science. This human enquiry into Nature leads to a reflection on the human understanding of Nature and the humans’ place in Nature.From the writings and stories of great scientists selected from influential literatures, students can gain a general understanding of the concepts and methodology of science, and of how scientists relate their academic pursuit to contemporary life, thereby developing their own perspectives on scientific issues. Students will be required to read, discuss and write about a wide range of texts in philosophy, science and its history. Emphasis will be placed on students’ capacity to respond critically to these texts in written as well as oral presentations. Through these learning activities, students are expected to develop a lifelong capacity and enthusiasm to continue such dialogues with science texts in the future.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to   comprehend and discuss selected texts related to science, technology and nature;    identify the essential characteristics of how human beings view Nature;    formulate informed personal views on the societal implications of scientific explorations;    relate the developments in natural sciences highlighted in the course to contemporary human conditions;    evaluate the scopes of application, achievements and limitations of highlighted scientific methods.
syllabus: The topics numbered (1, 2 and 3) below indicate the core contents that MUST be covered in the course. In each topic, at least 3 subtopics (a, b, c and d) should be covered. 1. Human Exploration of the Physical Universe a. What is truth? b. How to find scientific truth? The importance of reason and experiments. c. How to express scientific truth? Mathematical formulation of natural laws. d. Expansion of the universe.   2. Human Exploration of the World of Life. a. Laws of life: Natural selection and evolution. b. Code of life: The discovery of DNA. c. Manipulation of life and consequences: DNA and medicine. d. Manipulation of life and consequences: Pollution.   3. Our Understanding of Human Understanding a. What is the human mind and how does it work? b. Limitations of scientific method. c. What do Chinese know about Nature? -- Yin and Yang, five elements. d. Western culture versus Chinese culture.
required_readings: The required readings are those mentioned in the syllabus.  Plato. Republic. Trans. C.D.C. Reeve. Indianapolis: Hackett Publishing, 2004.  Selection: 506d (Book VI) to 517e (Book VII)  Newton, Isaac. The Principia: Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy. Trans. I. Bernard Cohen and Anne Whitman. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1999.  Selection:   Definitions: Definitions 1-5 (pp.403-406), last paragraph of Definition 6 (p. 408)  Axioms, or the Laws of Motion: Laws 1-3 (pp. 416-417), Corollary 6 with Proposition 1 (pp. 443-445)  Book 3: Rules for the Study of Natural Philosophy (pp.794-796)  General Scholium (pp.939-944)]    Darwin, Charles. On the Origin of Species. London: John Murray, 1859.  Selection: Chapter 4 (Para. 1-6, 9-18, 39-46, 50-63, 68-71)  Watson, James D. with Andrew Berry. DNA: The Secret of Life. New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2003.  Selection: Chapter 1 (Para. 1-36), Chapter 2 (whole)  Poincaré, Henri. Science and Method. Trans. Francis Maitland. Rpt. In Poincaré, Henri. The Value of Science: Essential Writings of Henri Poincare. New York: Modern Library. 2001.  Selection: Chapters I and III  Kandel, Eric R. In Search of Memory: The Emergence of a New Science of Mind. New York: W. W. Norton & Company, 2006.  Selection: Chapter 4 (Para. 1-9), Chapter 28 (whole)  Ronan, Colin A. The Shorter Science and Civilisation in China: An Abridgement of Joseph Needham’s Original Text. Vol. 1. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1978.  Selection: Chapter 10 (Para. 1-3, 13-42)  Leopold, Aldo. A Sand County Almanac and Sketches Here and There. New York: Oxford University Press, 2020.  Selection:   Foreword (pp. xxi-xxiii)  Part I: February–Good Oak (pp. 6-16)  Part II: Arizona and New Mexico–Thinking Like a Mountain (pp. 120-123)  Part III: The Upshot–The Land Ethic (pp. 190-212)
recommended_readings: There are three groups of suggested readings. 1.       Human Explorations of the Physical Universe  Grant, Edward. Physical Science in the Middle Ages. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1977.  The Cambridge History of Science Vol. 4 (Eighteenth-Century Science). Ed.  Roy Porter. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 2003.  Aristotle. Physics. Trans. C.D.C. Reeve. Indianapolis: Hackett Publishing, 2018.  Kuhn, Thomas. The Structure of Scientific Revolution. 3 ed. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1996.  Popper, Karl. Conjectures and Refutations. 2 ed. London and New York: Routledge, 2002. 2.       Human Explorations of the World of Life  Schrödinger, Erwin. What is Life? Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2012.  Dawkins, Richard. The Selfish Gene. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1976.  Houghton, John. Global Warming: The Complete Briefing. 5 ed. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2015. 3.       Our Understanding of Human Understanding  Schrödinger, Erwin. Mind and Matter. Rpt. in Schrödinger, Erwin. What is Life? Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2012.  Needham, Joseph. Science and Civilisation in China Volume 7: The Social Background, Part 2, General Conclusions and Reflections. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2004.  陳方正，《繼承與叛逆：現代科學為何出現於西方（增訂版）》，中華書局，2021。  陳天機、許倬雲、關子尹編，《系統視野與宇宙人生》，商務印書館，2004。  陳天機，《大自然與文化》，中文大學出版社，2004。  陳天機，《天羅地網》，牛津大學出版社，2008。  Penrose, Roger. The Emperor's New Mind. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002.

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 407
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02

title: In Dialogue with Nature (Cross-institutional)
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGFN1000.
description: This course is an intellectual pursuit across various natural sciences including the two most fundamental ones, physical and biological sciences. Ancient Greek philosophers took the lead in exploring the physical world and the world of life with reason and hence laid the foundations of natural science. This human enquiry into Nature leads to a reflection on the human understanding of Nature and the humans’ place in Nature.From the writings and stories of great scientists selected from influential literatures, students can gain a general understanding of the concepts and methodology of science, and of how scientists relate their academic pursuit to contemporary life, thereby developing their own perspectives on scientific issues. Students will be required to read, discuss and write about a wide range of texts in philosophy, science and its history. Emphasis will be placed on students’ capacity to respond critically to these texts in written as well as oral presentations. Through these learning activities, students are expected to develop a lifelong capacity and enthusiasm to continue such dialogues with science texts in the future.The content of this course is identical to that of “In Dialogue with Nature” (UGFN1000). The mode of delivery is blended. Teaching and learning activities are mainly conducted online but there are also several onsite meetings. Students taking this course come from different UGC-funded institutions.Blended-mode class section is available for this course. Please refer to the “Class Notes” of the blended-mode class section for details.
